ABATAGOUSH,
A large bay on Lake Mistassini, North West Territories, 290 miles from Lake St. John, 333½ miles north of Montreal. On it is a Hudson Bay Company's trading post.

ABATAMAGOMAW,
A lake of the North West Territories, near the height of land dividing the waters of the St. Lawrence from those of Hudson's Bay, 272 miles N. of Montreal, 10 miles N. W. of Lake Nikouban. It is about 12 miles long from N. E. to S. W., and 5 miles wide from S. E. to N. W. It is crowded with low rocky islands, on some of which, as well as on the mainland, there are some large timber. Copper and iron ore are found on the margin of the lake, and limestone and building stones are abundant. Lake Abatamagomaw has its outlet in the S. W. part by a stream which forms one of the branches of the Notaway River, which empties into James's Bay.

ABBITIBBI,
A lake of the North West Territories, in lat. 49° N., lon. 78° 10' W. Length 60 miles; breadth 20 miles. It is studded with numerous islands, and has its outlet in Abbittibbi River. There is a trading post of the Hudson's Bay Company on its S. E. shore.

ABBITIBBI,
A river of the North West Territories, takes its rise in the high lands above Lake Temiscamingue, about lat. 48° 10' N., lon. 29° 30' W., and after a course of 200 miles joins the Moose River, a large stream running into James's Bay, at Moose Factory.

ALBANY,
A river of the North West Territories, takes its rise in lake St. Joseph, lat. 51° N., lon. 90° 20' W., and falls into James's Bay. Total length 320 miles. About 126 miles from its estuary it spreads into numerous branches extending far to the westward and southward, and forming a complete chain of communication with the waters of Lake Superior, Lake Winnipeg and Severn River. The Hudson's Bay Company have four trading posts on this river.

ARCTIC OCEAN.

(Named from the Greek word Arctos, the "Bear," the constellation of which is principally included within the celestial Arctic Circle), that portion of the Northern Sea extending from the Arctic Circle to the North Pole. The Arctic Ocean enters deeply, in the form of gulfs, bays, etc., into the N. parts of the continent of Europe, Asia and America. The chief of these indentations are the White Sea, in Europe; Sea of Kara, Gulfs of Obi and Yenisei, in Siberia and Baffin's Bay in North America. It is united to the Pacific by Behring's Straits, and to the Atlantic by a wide sea extending from Greenland on the W., to Norway and Lapland on the E. This portion of the Arctic Ocean contains one of the largest archipelagos on the globe. The middle of it is occupied by Greenland, and on the E. is an extensive group of islands, known under the name of Spitzbergen, the small island of Jan Mayen and Iceland. West of Greenland, and divided from it by Davis's Straits and Baffin's Bay, there are a number of islands of great size belonging to the Dominion of Canada. The regions embraced by the more restricted limits of the Arctic Ocean (namely, from lat. 70° N.) are perhaps the most dreary and desolate on the face of the globe. Their shores are covered with eternal snows, and the entire surface of their seas with large fields and huge masses of floating ice, in perpetual motion, and whose constant and tremendous collisions are attended with the most appalling sounds. Dense fogs, violent storms and endless nights, add to the horror of the scene. There is but one month in the year (July) in which snow does not fall. The Arctic Ocean freezes even in summer; and, during the eight winter months, a continuous body of ice extends in every direction from the pole, filling the area of a circle between 3,000 and 4,000 miles in diameter. Some of the masses of ice that line the shores of this ocean, extend many miles in length, and present sea fronts of 200 feet in height; while fields of ice 20 or 30 miles in diameter, and from 10 to 40 feet in thickness, are frequent, and sometimes extend over 100 miles, so closely packed together that no opening is left between them. They are also found to have a violent rotary motion, by which they are dashed against one another with tremendous force. The icebergs, of which vast numbers are seen floating about, vary from a few yards to miles in circumference, and rise to several hundreds of feet in height. The ice in these regions is very transparent and compact, and remarkable for the variety and beauty of its tint. The water of the Arctic Ocean is extremely pure, shells being distinctly visible at a depth of 80 fathoms. The first attempt to navigate this sea was made in 1500. From 1745, England, anxious to find out a shorter passage to her East India possessions than round by the Cape of Good Hope, despatched successive expeditions to the northern coast of America, and offered a reward of £10,000 to the successful discoverer of a north-west passage. At length, in 1852, Sir Robert McClure made this passage; Sir John Franklin completed the passage in 1845-46, but neither himself or crew ever returned. In 1857-59 Sir Leopold McClintock found at King William's Island a record of his death and of his lost expedition.

ASSINIBOINE.
A large river in Manitoba, rises about lat. 52° N., long. 103° W., and after flowing southerly for about 130 miles, winds to the E., and discharges into the Red River at the city of Winnipeg, 30 miles above its mouth in Lake Winnipeg. The Hudson's Bay Company have several trading posts on this river. It is navigable, spring and early summer, as far as Fort Ellice.

ATHABASCA LAKE,
Or Lake of The Hills, of the North West Territories, is next to Slave Lake in superficies, and is situated about 180 miles S. W. of it, lat. 51° N., lon. from 106° to 112° W. It is an elongated body of water 230 miles in length, and averaging 14 miles in width. Near its S. W. extremity it receives the Athabasca River, which rises in the Rocky Mountains and flows N. E. to join it after a long and tortuous course. Lake Athabasca discharges its waters northward by Slave River, and it communicates both through the Slave Lake and Mackenzie River with the Polar Sea, and through Wollaston and Deer Lakes, and Churchill River, with Hudson's Bay. The shores of the Athabasca to the northward are high syenite rock; those to the southward are alluvial, but advancing eastwardly they rise into barren sandy hills, perfectly divested of vegetable growth. On Athabasca River, lat. 54° 20' N., lon. 114° 3' E., is Fort Assiniboine.

BEAR LAKE, GREAT
(I.e. the lake lying under the constellation of the Great Bear, being intersected from the Arctic—from Arctos, "bear,"—Circle)—a lake of the North West Territories, between lat. 65° and 67° N., and lon. 117° and 123° W. Shape very irregular; area may be estimated at 14,000 square miles; height above the sea at 230 feet. Its depth has never been ascertained; but where tried no bottom was found with 270 feet line. The water is remarkably transparent, and appears of a light blue color. The lake abounds with fish. It discharges its waters by Bear River into the Mackenzie. It remains frozen over from December to June.

BIG ATHABASCA.
A river of the North West Territories, draws its water-shed from the glaciers of Mount Brown, the highest peak (6600 feet) of the Rocky Mountains, and also from a much lower height, called the Miette, not far from the Leather or Yellow Head Pass. Length a little under a thousand miles. There is a large strata of pit coal all along either side of the river. The coal is found in seams from 15 to 30 feet in thickness.

BRANDON:
An incorporated city on the south bank of the Assiniboine River, 182 miles west of Winnipeg. Brandon was first settled in 1881, on the completion of the Canadian Pacific Railway to that point; incorporated as a city in 1882. It has increased in population very rapidly, and is second to Winnipeg in size and importance. Its streets are well graded and shaded with trees.

It is located in one of the finest agricultural sections in the North West. All classes of business and professions are represented.

There are grain elevators, joint capacity 150,000 bush., grist mills, saw and planing mills, and the division shops of the Canadian Pacific Railway. An efficient Fire Department, with steam fire engine, western juridical jail, court house, public schools, convent and churches of all denominations. Population, 3,500. Stages leave Brandon as follows:

For Rapid City, Monday, Wednesday, Friday, 2.45 p.m. Leave Rapid City Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday, 7 a.m.

For Beresford and Souris (Plumb Creek), Friday, 7 a.m., Tuesday, 2 p.m. Leave Souris, Monday, 7.30 a.m., Thursday, 7 a.m.

For Routhwaite, Wawonaisa, Milford, Two Rivers, Monday and Thursday, 7 a.m. Leave Two Rivers Tuesday and Friday, 7 a.m.

For Hazelwood, Carrolltown, Sheppard Ferry, Sheppardville, Turtle Mountain, Deloraine, Friday 7 a.m. Leave Deloraine Tuesday, 6 a.m.

For Beresford, Monteith, Melgund, Napi, Menota, Friday, 7 a.m. Leave Menota Tuesday, 1 p.m.

For Pendennis, Friday, 3 p.m. Leave Pendennis, Friday 7 p.m.

THE CHALLENGE WIND-MILL,
ONE MAN TO FORTY HORSE-POWER.

ITS SIMPLICITY CONTRASTED.

1. The sliding head on our Mill is connected with the sails by a straight jointed lever, which is the simplest and most direct connection that is possible to make. In all other self-governing mills (so called) this connection is made by levers, links and quadrants, and is indirect and inefficient.

2. Our sails are supported at the two extremities of the pivoting bar and also at the head of the sail, and at the same time are moved in and out of the wind, from the head of the sail, so that the longest leverage is secured; hence there is less strain on the sails, and they are firm and uniform in their motion.

In all other mills the sails are supported and moved in the line of the pivoting bar only, and therefore can neither rest firmly nor be moved readily or uniformly.

In these particulars no other mill compares with ours, and it is difficult to conceive of any possible improvement.

ITS SUPERIORITY CONTRASTED.

1. It is simpler, stronger and more durable than any other wind-mill.

2. It is under perfect control of the operator, and in his absence is so guarded that it will stop in case of any accident.

3. It is held into the wind by a weighted lever within the reach of the operator, whereas in other mills the sails are held out of the wind, and the weighted lever is beyond the reach of the operator.

4. Its normal state is at rest, and it only runs when the weight is upon the lever. If the weight is removed or if any of the connections between the weight and the sails are broken, the mill stops. In other mills the opposite are the facts.

5. Its available power is 25 per cent. greater than any other mill.

6. Its governor is more sensitive and efficient than that of any other mill.

7. No possible accident can cause it to "run away," and no wind can "uncap it," or blow it down without taking the tower with it. In these respects it is superior to any other mill.

8. Its sliding head connections are so direct, and the supporters and leverage of its sails are so perfect, that no other mill can be made to compete with it except by infringing these patented peculiarities.

The above cut shows our Pumping Mill, with sails spread ready for work, but our Geared or Power-Wind Mills are mostly "DOUBLE HEADERS," this is two wheels on one shaft, and has double the power of any other mill in existence.

CHESTERFIELD INLET,
A long and narrow inlet of the North West Territories, stretching N. from Hudson's Bay. Entrance in lat. 63° 30' N., lon. 90° 40' W. Length 250 miles; greatest breadth 25 miles.

CHIBOGOMOU,
A lake of the North West Territories, 288 miles N. of Montreal, and over 200 miles from Lake St. John. It stretches to the N. E. some 25 miles, and empties by two outlets into another parallel lake on the N. W. side. These lakes have their outlet into the Notaway River, a stream flowing into James's Bay. The Chibogomou Lake is studded with numerous low and elongated islands, especially in its S. E. extension. They are often rocky. The shores of the lake are also low and rocky, thickly covered with moss. Green wood surrounds the lake, except in the neighborhood of Paint Mountain, where the forest has been burned.

CHUMAH,
A post office in Oak river settlement, Tp. 14, R. 24. Nearest railway, telegraph and express offices, Griswold, distant 30 miles. Has Methodist and Presbyterian churches and 4 public schools. Mail weekly.

Carridge James, postmaster

CHURCHILL,
Called also MISSISSIPI and ENGLISH RIVER, a river of the North West Territories, rising in Lake Methye, lat. 51° 10' N., lon. 108° 30' W., first flowing S. E. through Lakes Buffalo and La Crosse, then turning N. E. and running almost due E. to Nelson's Lake, whence it flows in a N. E. direction through two considerable lakes, and falls into Hudson's Bay after a course of about 700 miles, in lat. 45° N. It traverses a woody region, and is full of beaver, but is nevertheless navigable, portages being formed at the most difficult points. The Upper or Beaver River, portion of the Churchill River watershed, intermediate between the Saskatchewan and Mackenzie Red River systems, is a fine country for settlement. The soil is good and stony, well wooded with magnificent pines and other valuable timber.

COPPERMINE RIVER,
In the North West Territories, enters an inlet of the Arctic Ocean, N.E. of the Great Bear Lake, after a course of about 250 miles. Its breadth varies from one hundred to three hundred yards; its waters are deep and its current extremely rapid. The Copper Mountains, which take their name from the copper found within them, are situated on the N.W. bank of a great bend of the river, in lat. 67° 19' 30" N., lon. 116° 25' 45" W. This river was explored in 1771.

DAVIS'S STRAIT,
Between the North West Territories of
Canada and Greenland; connects Baffin's
Bay with the Atlantic. Length about 750
miles. The narrowest part of the strait is
precisely at the point where it is intersected
by the Arctic Circle, being there 220 miles
broad, the widest being probably about
600 miles. The east coast is thickly strewed
throughout its whole length with rocks
and islets, and serrated with numerous
narrow inlets, which penetrate a good way
into the land. The west coast has fewer,
but larger, indentations, the most extensive
being Hudson's Strait and Northumberland
Inlet. Strong currents set from it south-
ward, and, though greatly encumbered with
ice, it is much frequented by whaling ships.

CAMERON does the business in his line—employs over 50 Hands,
and has the Nobby Trade, 490 Main Street, Winnipeg.
Named in honor of the celebrated navigator, John Davis, who discovered this strait in 1585.

**Dease River,**  
Of the North West Territories, rising in the Coppermine Mountains, and flowing into the N. side of Great Bear Lake. Named, as well as the following strait, after Lieut. Dease, one of the party who first explored it in 1837 by order of the Hudson's Bay Company.

**Dease Strait,**  
A channel in the Arctic Ocean, communicating with Coronation Gulf, and having Melbourne Island at its E. extremity; intersected by the parallel of 60° N. It is about 120 miles long and 25 miles average breadth, and at its widest part is considerably obstructed by islands.

**Deer Lake,**  
Of the North West Territories, between 56° 30' and 58° N. lat., and in 102 W. lon. Length from 150 to 200 miles; breadth 25 miles. A serpentine strait connects it towards the north with Lake Wollaston, and to the south it has an outlet into Churchill River. Deer Lake is extremely deep, and its waters remarkably clear.

EAST SELKIRK,
An incorporated town, with mayor and council, on the main line of the C. P. R., 21 miles north of Winnipeg. Daily mails and trains. Communication with West Selkirk by opposite side of Red River, by a carriage ferry. Head of deep water navigation on Red River for lake trade. Is situated on high banks, and is said to have the best harbor on the Red River. Has also a deep inland harbor on Cook's Creek. The track of the C.P.R. extends through the town down to the lumber yards and brick yards on the river. The quarries here are the largest and finest in the Province, and are a favorite resort of geologists. Fish-packing and the well known potteries are amongst the most thriving industries. 5 general stores, 4 hotels, Protestant and separate schools. Population 400.

EMERSON,
A town, at the international boundary, incorporated in 1880. Amalgamated in 1883 with West Lynn, a town on the west bank of the Red River. A free traffic and railway bridge unites both sections. Stage leaves Emerson for Gauthier, Wednesday and Saturday, 1 p.m.; leaves Gauthier.

FORT ALEXANDER,
A Hudson Bay post on the east shore of Lake Winnipeg, at the mouth of Winnipeg River in an Indian Reserve. Distant from Winnipeg — miles. There are Roman Catholic and Episcopal churches and schools in the Reserve. Mails fortnightly. Nearest railway, telegraph and express offices, Selkirk West, distant — miles. Stage leaves Fort Alexander for Peguis every alternate Monday; leaves Peguis every alternate Saturday.

FORT ELICE,
A Hudson Bay trading post and post office in Colville settlement. Mails twice a week. Nearest railway station, express and telegraph offices, Moosomin, distant 30 miles. Has a Roman Catholic church and mission school. Occasional services are held by Presbyterian ministers. Stage leaves Fort Ellice for Assiniboia Friday, 3 p.m., returning Sunday, 7 p.m.; Fort Ellice to Binscarth, Silver Creek and Shell River, every Friday; leave Shell River, every Saturday; Fort Ellice to De Clare, Wednesday, 1 p.m.; leave De Clare, Thursday, 7 a.m.

FORT WILLIAM, ONT.

A station on the main line of the C.P.R., 6 miles west of Port Arthur, in the district of Algoma, on the banks of the River Kaministiquia, emptying into Thunder Bay. The scenery is grand, and overhanging the town is an immense mountain nearly 1,000 feet high, and having an almost perpendicular front. The round house and machine shops belonging to the Eastern division of the Canadian Pacific railway are established here, and give employment to a large number of men. Large elevators and docks are built on the river front. A large lumber business is carried on. It contains a Presbyterian church, public school, one large first-class hotel and a large number of small ones and a saw mill. In the vicinity is the Roman catholic mission, containing church and schools. Services of the Episcopal church are held in the school house. C.P.R. Telegraph Co. and Dominion Express Co. have an office here. Population 250.

Length 240 miles; medium breadth 30 miles. Its shores on both sides are rugged and mountainous. It was discovered in 1576 by Sir Martin Frobisher.

GREAT FISH RIVER,
(or Thew-ee-Choh,) a river of the North West Territories, rises on Sussex Lake on the N.E. side of Great Slave Lake, and, after a tortuous N.E. course, enters an inlet of the Arctic Ocean in lat. 67 deg. 7 m. 31 sec. N, lon. 94 deg. 39 m. 45 sec. W.

GREAT SAND HILLS,
N. of Sidewood station C.P.R.

GREAT SLAVE LAKE,
(Lac de L'Esclave, "Lake of the Slave"), an extensive lake of the North West Territories, situated between lat. 69 deg. 40 m. and 63 deg. N., and lon. 109 deg. 30 m. and 117 deg. 30 m. W. The shape is very irregular. Length from E. to W. 300 miles; greatest breadth 50 miles. The shores, on its N. side especially, are precipitous and rugged, and it contains many rocky and wooded islands. It receives from the N.E. the surplus waters of Athabasca and Artillery Lakes, and from the S. those of Lake Athabasca by the Slave River. It discharges its own by the Mackenzie River into the Arctic Ocean. It is wholly frozen over for six months of the year.

GREAT SLAVE RIVER,
Of the North West Territories, formed by the Peace River, after it is joined by Stony River from Lake Athabasca. It enters Great Slave Lake on its south side by two mouths, near Fort Resolution. Total course 300 miles. The shores, in many parts, are well wooded. In its upper part it is interrupted by rapids and falls; its lower course is through an alluvial region. Magnificent scenery skirts its banks.

HAYES RIVER, or HILL RIVER,
In the North West Territories; rises near Lake Winnipeg, and flows N.E. through Hole, Knee, and Swampy Lakes, and, after a course estimated at upwards of 300 miles, enters James's Bay at York. Lat. 56 deg. 35 m. N., lon. 92 deg. 30 m. W. Its banks are steep and in many places bordered by fine woods. Its affluents are Fox River and Shamatawa. Oxford House and Rock house are stations on the river; at its mouth, between it and Nelson River, on the west side, is Hayes Island.

HUDSON'S BAY,
An inland sea of the North West Territories, between lat. 51° and 64° N., and lon. 77° and 95° W., enclosed by Canadian territory on all sides except the N.E., where it communicates with Davis Strait by Hudson's Strait. Length from N. to S. 850 miles; breadth 600 miles. Its south part is named James' Bay, and receives the Albany, Moose and other rivers. Hudson's Bay has bold shores and numerous islands, reefs and sandbanks, and on its coasts several settlements of the Hudson's Bay Company; it is free from ice and navigable for only a few months in the year. The beluga, or white whale, is occasionally found in its waters, but fish, also crustaceans, are scarce.

HUDSON'S STRAIT,
Between lat. 60° and 64° N., lon. 65° and 77° W., connects Hudson's Bay with the Atlantic Ocean and Davis' Strait, and is about 450 miles in length, with an average breadth of 100 miles, though in its narrowest part but about 60 miles.

KENOGAMI or LONG LAKE,
Of the North West Territories, N. of Lake Superior, is 54½ miles long by 1½ miles broad. Its shore line measures 192 miles, exclusive of islands. The country around the southern part of the lake is rugged and mountainous, with very little covering of any kind upon the hard quartz rocks. The following rivers enter the west side:—Hane's River, Kawesagagama, or Point River, Kamiskatiwaga, or Black Water River, and Kivungie, or Pike River; on the east side, Making Ground River. The Canada Pacific railway will cross this lake. Oats and barley have been successfully cultivated at Long Lake House. Lat. 49° 46' 30" N., long. 86° 46' W. Flax, potatoes, and all the ordinary vegetables also thrive remarkably well.

LAKE REGION,
A section of country west of the highlands at the head of Lake Superior, on the streams tributary to Rainy Lake, which are so numerous that it would be difficult to say whether the country would be better described as one vast lake with ridges of land running through it, or as land everywhere intersected by water. The lakes are studded with wooded islands, which are so sheltered that the smallest canoes are rarely windbound.

LAKE WINNIPEG,
A lake of Manitoba, is between lat. 50 deg. and 54 deg. N., and lon. 96 deg. and 99 deg. W. Length 240 miles; breadth 55 miles; shape very irregular. The shores are low, and its waters are muddy. (In Algonquin Winnipeg means "dirty water.") Among its affluents from the east are Red River and the large and beautiful Winnipeg River. Its only tributary from the south is Red River, and among its many tributaries from the west are Dauphin or Little Saskatchewan River and the Great Saskatchewan River. It has no affluent from the north. It discharges its own surplus waters northwardly into the Nelson River through Pigeon Green Lake, into Hudson's Bay. On its shores are several stations of the Hudson's Bay Company, the Iceland settlement on its west shore and a number of lumber mills on the east shore. A large amount of white fish are yearly shipped to eastern cities.

circumference 300 miles. Compared with other lakes, it deserves a high rank in the scale of beauty. The scenery is wild and romantic in a high degree; its shores, which are much indented with bays, being faced with precipices and crowned with hills and knobs of various heights, clad with a dense foliage of shrubbery and evergreens. Its surface beautifully studded with countless islands of various sizes and forms, said to number 12,000, producing an effect surpassing that of the far-famed Thousand Islands of the St. Lawrence, disclosing between them the continued sheet of its wide-spreading waters, the extent of which enlarges upon the vision as the traveler advances upon the lake, till the mainland is shut out from view by the islands that multiply around him. On the islands and mainland the outcrops have been traced for more than twenty miles, and large deposits of gold quartz have been found. Several mining companies have been organized to work the mines, which are very valuable. There are only two mines working, owing to a want of capital, and they have not reached a depth exceeding 150 feet. The ground increases in richness, and the seam or pay streak gradually widens. The stamp mills hitherto in use are so small that correct milling returns have not yet been obtained; but they have been received show from $10 to $14 a ton. The accessibility of the locations make them capable of being worked at far less cost than any mines yet discovered upon the continent. The lake receives the Rainy River from the south, and northward gives origin to the Winnipeg River.

MANITOBA,
A province of the Dominion of Canada, bounded E. by the province of Ontario on the S. by the United States, and on the N. E. and W. by the North West Territories of the Dominion. It extends from 49° to 52° 15' N. lat., and from 95° to 101° 50' W. lon., and comprises an area of 86,340 square miles.

The name Manitoba, taken from a large lake, a part of which lies in the province, is a contraction made by the old French Canadian voyageurs of the Cree word Manitowahun. Manito signifies supernatural, divine spirit, and wahun means a strait. As the waters of a strait in that lake are agitated in an unusual way, the Indians believed formerly there was therein something supernatural, a spirit that moved them, and so they called the lake Manitowahun.

The agricultural capabilities of its soil cannot be exceeded for many things. The most part of the province is prairie land, perfectly level and diversified by groups of elm, ash, oak, poplar, basswood, and ash-leaf maple (negondoo from ni folio). It is a rich, black mould resting partly on a limestone formation and partly on a thick coat of hard clay. Wheat ripens in 110 days, and gives an average return of 20 to 25 bushels to the acre. All kinds of garden vegetables, as well as oats, barley, Indian corn, hops, flax, hemp, potatoes, and other root crops are easily raised. The grassy savannas of Red River afford unlimited pasturage ranges, as long as unploughed.

The climate of Manitoba, though severe in winter, is nevertheless occasionally hot in summer. The mean for the three winter months of Dec., Jan., and Feb., is 5° below, and for the summer months of June, July, and August, 65°. Though the winter is extremely cold, it is mitigated by a dry atmosphere. A population more healthy than Manitobans cannot be met anywhere.

The principal rivers are the Assiniboine, 480 miles long, and Red River, 685 miles long, 525 of which are in the United States. The largest lakes (only a part of which, however, are in Manitoba) are Winnipeg, 280 miles long and 45 to 57 miles wide; Winnipegosass, 110 miles long and 6 to 20 miles wide; Manitoba, 110 miles long and 25 wide.

Manitoba is divided into five electoral districts for Dominion elections, viz.: Selkirk, Provencher, Lisgar, Marquette, and Winnipeg, each of which sends 1 member to the House of Commons.

Winnipeg is the capital of the Province. There are two bishops in the Province: the Archbishop of St. Boniface (Roman Catholic), residing at St. Boniface, east side of the Red River, facing Winnipeg, and the Metropolitan Bishop of Rupert's Land (Church of England), residing at St. John, Winnipeg.

The public affairs are administered by a Lieutenant Governor, an Executive Council of 5 members, and a Legislative Assembly of 31 members, elected every 4 years. Justice is dispensed by a Chief Justice and 3 puisne judges.

For a NOBBY SUIT TO ORDER, Go to CAMERON, 490 Main Street, Winnipeg.
All religious denominations are represented in the Province.

The Province is well provided with educational institutions. It has three colleges, St. John's (Church of England), St. Boniface (Roman Catholic), and Manitoba (Presbyterian), a Convent, 3 Protestant Ladies Schools, and 311 common schools, 271 amongst the Protestants and 40 amongst the Roman Catholics. The Sisters of Charity from Montreal have a large Convent at St. Boniface, an academy for young ladies, and orphanage, and four missions in the Province. The school system established by law is entirely denominational or separate.

The rapid increase in schools and school attendance during the thirteen years ending in 1883 will be more easily conceived by giving the figures, which are as follows:

| Year | No. of schools | Total attend. |
|------|---------------|--------------|
| 1871 | 16            | 816          |
| 1872 | 17            | 1,067        |
| 1873 | 17            | 1,108        |
| 1874 | 22            | 1,248        |
| 1875 | 26            | 1,595        |
| 1876 | 30            | 1,609        |
| 1877 | 38            | 2,027        |
| 1878 | 50            | 2,670        |
| 1879 | 99            | 3,614        |
| 1880 | 101           | 3,736        |
| 1881 | 128           | 4,919        |
| 1882 | 182           | 6,972        |
| 1883 | 271           | 10,831       |

It will be observed that during the last four years the increase in the number of schools, as well as attendance, has been nearly threefold, a rate of progress quite in keeping with the settlement of the province.

The Legislative grant for 1883 was $33,159.98, which, with a balance of $7,338.07 from 1882, made a total available fund of $40,498.05. After deducting from this sum the expenses of the board, for superintendence, inspection of schools, examination of teachers, and other necessary charges, there remained a sum of $22,418.28 for aid to schools, and a balance carried forward to next year of $9,753.33. The necessity of large expenditure on capital account for the provision of school accommodation for the rapidly increasing population of the province accounts for the large receipts from the issue of debentures, amounting to $176,016.80, of which $149,658.80 was for "cities and towns." It is considered a matter of regret that these debentures bear interest, in most cases as high as eight per cent. The Superintendent suggests the establishment of a fund upon the credit of the school lands of the province, from which loans might be obtained at a lower rate of interest.

In 1872 telegraphic communication was established between Manitoba and the United States.

Every bona-fide settler receives a home-stead or a free grant of 160 acres of land.

This section of North America was first visited by the French. Chevalier de la Verne-drye built a fort at the mouth of the Assiniboine in 1731. The French continued to trade there alone for many years, but in 1767 the first English traders visited it, and soon several rival companies were in operation. These finally dwindled into the famous North West Company, which, in its turn, was absorbed by the Hudson's Bay Company, chartered by King Charles II. in 1670. The latter company having sold a tract of land to the Hon. Thomas Douglas, Earl of Selkirk, on both sides of the Assiniboine and of the Red River, his lordship planted there, in 1812, a colony known by the name of Selkirk Settlement, Red River Settlement also Assiniboia. In 1836 the Hudson's Bay Company repurchased from the heirs of Lord Selkirk the same tract of land ceded to his lordship in 1811, and continued to exercise authority over that portion of Rupert's Land by the appointment of the Governor and Council of Assiniboia, which, in course of time, especially after the settlers had declared independence of trade in 1849, formed a rather independent administration for the local affairs in the colony, the limits of which extended but fifty miles around Fort Garry. It is that colony that now forms the greatest part of the new province of Manitoba.

The Hudson's Bay Company never claimed any proprietary rights on the North West Territories proper. These territories formerly included nothing but the lands east of the Rocky Mountains, watered by the rivers running towards the Arctic Sea. The Charter of the Company merely included Rupert's Land, i.e., the lands watered by the tributaries of Hudson's Bay.

These two immense portions of country outside of the province of Manitoba are now known by the name of North West Territories.

In March, 1869, the Hudson's Bay Company agreed to hand to the Imperial Government the territorial rights and governing responsibilities, and on the 16th of July, 1870, England handed the whole to the Canadian Government. It was during that period that the Red River troubles took place. The transactions between England and Canada, as well as the Hudson's Bay Company, having been made without consulting and even paying any attention to the government and people of Assiniboia, a deep feeling of uneasiness arose, and the Canadian authorities coming into the country before the transfer, demanded residence. In the meantime a provisional government was formed by the settlers to secure their rights and come to an agreement with the Dominion of Canada. Delegates were sent to Ottawa for that purpose, and treated with the proper authorities. England urged the Ottawa Government to satisfy the people of Red River. Then the Bill of Manitoba and other guarantees were agreed to, and thereby the entry of Manitoba into the Confederation was effected.

The main line of the Canadian Pacific Railway passes through the centre of the Province; there is nearly 700 miles of Railway in operation in the Province, which is expected will be more than doubled in a few years.

The first missionary known as having visited the country is the Rev. Père Messager, who ac-

Clark's Haricot Mutton in 2lb. tins, P.O. 342, Montreal.
compounded Chevalier de la Verandrye in 1734. At the time of the Conquest the Catholic missions were abandoned; they were resumed in 1818 by the Revs. J. N. Provencher and S. J. N. Dumoulin, from Quebec.

The Rev. J. N. Provencher was consecrated bishop of Joliette in 1822, and afterwards nominated bishop of St. Boniface. That see was created an Archdiocese in 1871, and is now occupied by the Most Rev. Alexandre Taché, D.D.

A Church of England bishopric was created in 1849. Rev. David Anderson was the first Bishop of Rupert's Land, and was succeeded by the Right Rev. Robert Macnary, D.D.

MORRIS,
An incorporated town on the Pemican Mountain section of the Canadian Pacific Ry., 43 miles south of Winnipeg in Provencher Co., Man., at the confluence of Morris and Red Rivers, 40 miles from Winnipeg. It has 4 churches, 2 mills, a printing office issuing a weekly paper, 8 stores, and 4 hotels. It is in the midst of one of the finest farming parts of the province. The great Lowe farm, the largest in the Canadian North West, comprising some 15,000 acres, is situated 10 miles from the town. Mails daily. Express and telegraph offices. It has Episcopal, Methodist and Presbyterian churches and public schools. Pop. 300.

NORTH WEST TERRITORIES
Geographical Position.—That portion of the possessions of the Dominion of Canada now generally known as the North West Territories, and which comprises an area of about 1,868,000 square miles, may be described as bounded on the east by the Province of Manitoba and that region of country known as the District of Keewatin; on the south by the dividing line between Canada and the United States, which is along the 49th parallel of latitude and which is designated and generally understood as The International Boundary; on the west by the Province of British Columbia and the Territory of Alaska; and on the north by the Frozen Ocean. To save space this country will hereafter be called the N.W. Territories.

Government.—For the due administration of law and order there is a Lieutenant-Governor over the N.W. Territories, appointed by and holding that office during the pleasure of the Governor-General of Canada, and performing his functions under instructions given him either by Order-in-Council or by the Secretary of State of Canada. The Lieutenant-Governor is assisted by a Council at present composed of 14 members, of whom 8 are electoral representatives, 3 are the survivors of the six who formed the first Council, and who were appointed by the Governor-General when the Territorial Government was inaugurated; and the remaining 3 are the Stipendiary Magistrates of the N.W. Territories, who are ex officio members of the Council. There is, in addition to these, a Clerk of the Council, appointed by the Governor-General, who also acts as secretary to the Lieutenant-Governor. The 8 elected members represent the electoral districts.
of Lorne, Edmonton, Broadview, Fort Qu'Appelle, Regina, Moose Jaw, Carlyle and Calgary. The present Lieutenant-Governor is Lieut.-Col. the Hon. E. Dewdney, who is also Indian Commissioner for the N.W. Territories. His seat of government is at Regina, which, however, may be changed from time to time by the Governor-General in Council. It will thus be seen that, owing to the rapid increase in the population of the N.W. Territories, it has already become necessary to put into active motion the machinery of the electoral law, which may be thus briefly explained:— Whenever any district not exceeding an area of 1,000 square miles attains to a population of not less than 1,000 persons of adult age—exclusive of aliens and uncivilized Indians—the Lieutenant-Governor is bound by the law in that behalf to erect such district into an electoral district, which is then entitled to elect a member of the Council or the Legislative Assembly, as the case may be; and when that district shall contain a population of 2,000 persons, qualified as aforesaid, it will be entitled to elect a second member. As soon as the members so elected shall arrive at the number of 21, the Council will cease, and the members so elected will be constituted and designated as the Legislative Assembly for the Territories. These members hold their seats for two years, when, unless re-elected, they must retire and be succeeded by others. Upon the death or resignation of a member, another election must be held.

Magistrates.—There are 3 stipendiary Magistrates to perform the functions pertaining to such office, and in addition to them the Commissioner of the North-West Mounted Police is also a stipendiary Magistrate ex officio. Since the organization of the N.W. Territories there have been appointed 98 Justices of the Peace, of whom 40 are members of the North-West Mounted Police, 9 are notaries public, and 45 are issuers of marriage licences; 63 notaries public, of whom 7 are also issuers of marriage licences; and 43 issuers of marriage licences including the 7 notaries public.

North-West Mounted Police.—The North-West Mounted Police is a most valuable arm of the government, especially of the N.W. Territories, and is composed of 2 officers, including 3 sergeants, and 520 non-commissioned officers and men, all under the command of the commissioner, Lieut.-Col. A. G. Irvine. The force is divided into five troops, each under the direction of a superintendent and two inspectors, in addition to which the adjutant and supply-officer rank as superintendents. The superintendents are ex officio Justices of the Peace and almost all of the inspectors have received like authority from the Lieutenant-Governor of the N.W. Territories. There are no municipal police forces in the N.W. Territories, but every member of the Mounted Police is invested with the authority of an ordinary police constable. Besides their police duties they also superintend the payment of treaty money to the various Indian bands. The headquarters of the force are at Regina, and the 5

very nearly along the 60th parallel of north latitude; and on the west by the Province of British Columbia.

DOMINION LAND AGENCIES.—Owing to the trend influx of settlers into the aforesaid provisional districts, the Dominion Government in the spring of 1884, found it absolutely necessary for the management of the lands which were being taken up in all directions, to establish smaller districts, designated Land Agencies, which have been laid out as follows:

In the eastern portion of Assiniboia—Touchwood, containing about 17,000 square miles; office at Touchwood Hills; land agent, Mr. John McTaggart. Qu'Appelle, containing about 15,000 square miles; office at Regina; land agent, Mr. W. H. Stevenson. Coteau, containing about 9,806 square miles; office at Carlyle; land agent, Mr. J. J. McLough. Swift Current, containing about 32,290 square miles, and comprising the greater part of the western portion of Assiniboia (of which district certain portions were included within the duties of the land agencies of Battleford and Calgary); office at Swift Current; land agent, Mr. W. M. Hilliard.

In Saskatchewan—The Land Agency of Prince Albert, situated in the eastern part of that district, containing about 28,708 square miles, with office at the Town of Prince Albert; land agent, Mr. Geo. Duff. Provision has been made for an agency called Battleford, in the western part of Saskatchewan and including within its duties a portion of the district of Assiniboia, containing about 39,663 square miles. For this land agency no agent has yet been appointed. In Alberta—The Land Agency of Calgary, situated in the southern part of the district, containing about 63,900 square miles, and including within its duties portions of the Districts of A-Similkameen and Kootenay; office at Calgary; agent Mr. J. McD. Gordon. Also, the Land Agency of Edmonton, situated in the northern part of the district, containing about 59,000 square miles, and including within its duties a portion of the district of Saskatchewan; office at Edmonton; agent, Mr. L. V. Guynnean.

These agencies are controlled by the Minister of the Interior at Ottawa, but, owing to the great distance which intervenes, they are under the general supervision of an officer—Mr. A. Walsh—styled the Commissioner of Dominion Lands, who is assisted by another officer—Mr. H. H. Smith—styled the Inspector of Dominion Lands Agencies, and having their headquarters at Winnipeg, Manitoba. These two gentlemen constitute what is called the Land Board, the object of which is to settle all disputes arising between settlers in regard to the occupation of Dominion Lands, and otherwise to arrange all matters relating to the general management of the same. The immense amount of work performed by the Department of the Interior in all its branches may be justly estimated upon a perusal of the Report of the Minister for the past year, which exhibits in detail the various and comprehensive labors connected with the settlement of the N.W. Territories.

REGISTRATION DISTRICTS.—Previous to the division of the N.W. Territories into Provisional Districts, Mr. W. J. Scott was appointed General Registrar for the whole country in question, but so rapid have been the development and settlement of that region that it became necessary to furnish the settlers with better registration facilities, and for this purpose 7 Registration Districts have been established. They are as follows:—In Saskatchewan, the Registration District of Prince Albert, with office at the town of that name; Mr. A. Sprout, registrar. In Assiniboia, the Registration Districts of Touchwood, Regina, Souris and the City of Regina, all under one registrar, Mr. G. A. Montgomery, whose office is in the City of Regina. And in Alberta, the Registration Districts of Calgary and Edmonton; for the former of these two Mr. T. A. McClean has recently been appointed registrar, with office at Calgary, but for Edmonton no appointment has yet been made. Registrations affecting lands outside the boundaries of the aforesaid 7 Registration Districts are still made by Mr. Scott, whose office is at Battleford.

POST OFFICES.—There are now sixty post offices in the N.W. Territories, of which 40 are in Assiniboia, 10 in Saskatchewan and 10 in Alberta.

INDIANS.—When the Dominion of Canada acquired possession of the N.W. Territories there were numerous bodies of roving Indians of different tribes, with whom treaties were made, and who were gathered together in large and placed in certain suitable localities—termed Indian Reservations—set apart for that purpose, and such has been the beneficial result of this action of the Government towards these people that already a large percentage of them are permanently settled and steadily engaged in agricultural pursuits. Every Reservation has its resident agent and farm instructor, whose duties are to assist the Indians in acquiring a thorough knowledge of agriculture. Three Industrial Schools for the instruction of Indian children in mechanical arts and agriculture have also been established, and are situated: One at Battleford in Saskatchewan, another near Qu'Appelle, in Assiniboia, and a third at High River, in Alberta.

PACIFIC HOTEL,
PORT ARTHUR, Ont.

JOHN SINCLAIR, Proprietor,
Late of GRAND CENTRAL & QUEEN'S HOTEL, Winnipeg.

PORT ARTHUR, Ontario,

An incorporated town on the shores of Thunder Bay. It is situated in the midst of a rich mineral region, where are found gold, silver, copper, iron, lead and numerous other minerals. It is the lake terminus of the Thunder Bay division of the Canadian Pacific railway, where the vast products of Manitoba and the Great North West are transhipped, and where the immense cargoes of general merchandise necessary to supply the large population of the western prairies are transferred from water to rail, to the Canadian Pacific railway lake steamships. Steamerers of the Northwestern Transportation Co., of Sault Ste. Marie, and the Collingwood and Lake Superior Transit Co., run here regularly. As a shipping port it ranks very high. For the fiscal year ending 30th June, 1884, the number of vessels reported 837, with a tonnage of 450,559 tons, and crews numbering 1,767. A fashionable watering place will soon spring up here, as the scenery is unsurpassed, and the coolness of the lake breezes during the entire summer will attract a large number of tourists and health seekers. Two newspapers are published, the Thunder Bay Sentinel (a daily), established in 1875, containing the general local news of the district, and the Herald (weekly). There are 4 churches: Episcopal, Methodist, Presbyterian and Roman Catholic, also a large public school and convent. A very commodious town hall occupies a prominent position. Several large hotels, with first-class accommodation, and a number of smaller ones, supply the wants of travellers. It is also the seat of the Judicial district, and boasts of a very handsome Court house and jail. Sittings of the District Court are held twice a year, and the Division Court once a month. A large trade in fresh fish is carried on here. For lovers of the piscatorial art there are innumerable small streams and lakes, in which the choicest speckled trout abound. Distant from Collingwood nearly 700 miles; from Winnipeg 428 miles. Population about 4,500.

PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE,
An incorporated town on the main line of the Canadian Pacific railway, 69 miles W. of Winnipeg. It has, besides the usual buildings—churches, 2 flour mills, a saw mill, stores, hotels, bank agency, a telegraph office, and 2 printing offices issuing weekly papers. It is surrounded by a fine farming country, with enough wood for actual settlement. Population 3,500.

Stages leave Portage la Prairie for Indianapolis, Teigneme, Olive, Camille and Lattleton, Friday, 7 a.m.; leave Lattleton, Wednesday, 7 a.m.; Portage la Prairie to Oakland, Wednesday, 7 a.m.; leave Oakland, Wednesday, 12:30 p.m.

QU'APPELLE RIVER,

RAINY LAKE,
In Manitoba, 250 miles west of Lake Superior, forms part of the boundary between the Canadian and United States territories. It is 50 miles long by 38½ broad, and 291 miles around by canoe route, and contains over 500 islands. It discharges its surplus waters into Lake of the Woods by Rainy River, 100 miles in length. Its banks are covered with small timber.

RAINY RIVER,
Connects Rainy Lake with Lake of the Woods. Is 160 miles long, and forms part of the boundary line between Manitoba and the United States.

RED DEER,

REDPATH,
A post settlement on the banks of Cut Arm Creek. Mail weekly; nearest railway, telegraph and express offices, Moosomin.

RED RIVER OF THE NORTH,
Rises in Elbow Lake, in the west of Minnesota, in about lat. 47° 7' N., lon. 98° 26' W., and flowing in a general south, then in a south-west, and afterwards in a north-west direction, at various nearly north, and crossing the northern boundary of the United States, falls into Lake Winnipeg, in Manitoba. Entire length 665 miles, 526 of which are in the United States. In the first 100 miles of its course it forms the line of connection between a multitude of small lakes, which seem to be disposed along the stream like beads upon a thread. A steamer has plied on Red River since 1869.

REED LAKE,
At Rush Lake station, in the Province of Assiniboine, 6 miles long by 3 miles wide.

REED RIVER,
empties in the north-west corner of Lake of the Woods.

REGINA,
356 miles west of Winnipeg. It is the capital of the North West Territories and is situated on the Wascana (or Pile of Bones River) in the centre of a large grain growing district. The headquarters of the Indian department and the mounted police are situated here. The Council chamber of the North West Council is a fine building and an ornament to the town. A court house, jail and an asylum are to be built shortly. The Canada North West Land Co. have built a large reservoir at the southern boundary of the town, which makes quite a lake, being in some places nearly half a mile wide and extending up the river 5 miles, with an average depth of 10 feet. It has a flour mill, planing mill and elevator, to be erected soon. Episcopal, Methodist and Presbyterian churches, and public schools. A weekly paper, The Leader, is published here. Mails daily. Express and telegraph offices. Population about 1,000. Stages leave Regina for Carstairs, Friday, 2 p.m.; leave Carstairs, Friday, 7 a.m.; leave Regina for Susser and Long Lake, Saturday, 9 a.m.

ROCKY MOUNTAINS, called also the CHIPPEWAYAN MOUNTAINS,

A chain in the central and west part of North America, commencing in New Mexico, in about 32° 30' N. lat., near Fort Webster, it extends nearly N.N.W., throughout the northern portion of the continent and the Polar Ocean, terminating west of the mouth of the Mackenzie River, in lat. 69° N., lon. 135° W. This range, in connection with the Andes, of which it may be said to be a continuation, forms the longest, and, according to Humboldt, the most uniform chain of mountains on the globe. Somewhat more than half of the entire chain belongs to North America, the name Rocky Mountains, being usually applied to that portion only which is comprised within the United States and Dominion of Canada, although the exact limit of this mountain range towards the south can scarcely be said to be determined. The entire length, however, of the chain, following the windings, may be stated in round numbers at 3,000 miles. The east boundary of the Rocky Mountains in lat. 39° N., is in 107° 20' W. lon.; in lat. 40° N., 108° 30' W. lon.; in lat. 63° N., 124° 40' W. lon.; in lat. 69° N., 130° 30' W. lon.

Notwithstanding this general tendency to the west, the continent widens so much more in the same direction that this chain, which, in South and Central America and Mexico is comparatively a coast range, is several hundred leagues inland in the United States and Canada. The highest known peaks within the United States are Fremont's, 13,570 feet; and Pike's Peak, 11,497 feet high; and Mount Brown and Mount Hooker, in Canada, near 53° N. lat., the former about 16,000 and the latter 15,690 feet above the sea level. We are very imperfectly acquainted with this system of mountains; the general altitude of the range, however, is supposed to vary from 10,000 to 14,000 feet; it is said that peaks have been measured of 18,000 feet in elevation. Probably no mountains of the same altitude can be so readily traversed as the Rocky Mountain chain, owing to the great breadth of its base and its gentle acclivity. Among the most remarkable of the numerous passes may be mentioned that leading from the head waters of the Athabasca to those of the Columbia between Mount Brown and Mount Hooker, and called the Athabasca Portage; it has a height of 7,300 feet, and has only been used by the traders of the Hudson's Bay Company as the principal pass into the basin of Columbia. The following are the measurement of 8 other passes in the Dominion of Canada:

1. Red Stone Creek or Boundary Pass from Waterlow River to the Kootanie, 6,030 feet above the sea.
2. British Kootanie Pass, by Ramsay River to the Kootanie, 5,960 feet.
3. "Pov's Nest Pass, by Crow River to the Kootanie.
4. Kootanee Pass, from Fort Bow by Ramsay River to the Kootanie (with a short tunnel, 4,600 feet), 6,086 feet.
5. Vermillion Pass, from the South Saskatchewan River by Fort Bow (4,100 feet) to the Kootanie, 4,247 feet.
6. Kicking Horse Pass, by Bow River and Kicking Horse River to the Upper Columbia, 5,250 feet.
7. Howse Pass, from Deer River by Blue-

berry river to the Upper Columbia, 6,347 feet.

6. Tele-Sanne or Yellowhead Pass, from the Athabasca to the Upper Fraser, 3,160 feet.

The principal pass on United States territory is the South Pass, in about lat. 42° 30' N., and lon. 109° 30' W. Its elevation is about 7,500 feet above the sea. The Union Pacific railroad crosses the Rocky Mountains near the sources of the Missouri and Columbia at an elevation of about 6,000 feet above the sea. Amid the valleys and forges of this stupendous system of mountains, some of the largest rivers of the globe have their birth. Of these the Athabasca, Peace, and Mackenzie find their outlet in the Polar Sea; the Saskatchewan in the Atlantic, through Hudson's Bay; the Missouri and its tributaries find an exit in Mississippi; while the Rio del Norte, the Colorado and the Columbia take opposite directions, the first through the valley of New Mexico to the Gulf of Mexico; the second through the deserts of Utah to the Gulf of California; while the last, from the N., bursting through the Cascade and contiguous ranges, rushes to join the mighty Pacific, bearing the only water that reaches that ocean directly from this range. On the geological structure of the Rocky Mountains little is as yet known. Volcanic rocks are known to exist in many places on the slopes or sides. According to the most recent reports there is, between the heads of Madison River and the upper waters of the Yellowstone, a volcanic region of perhaps 100 square miles in extent. Hot springs are found not only in this region, but in various other places on the east and west declivities of the Rocky Mountain range. Near 42° 37' N. lat., and 111° 45' W. lon., there are a number of fountains, the waters of which effervescence with the carbonic acid that they contain. From this circumstance they have received the name of "Beer, or Soda Springs." The most remarkable of these is Roseau, a jet of water about 3 feet high, accompanied with a subterraneous noise, which, together with the rushing of water, resembles the sound of a steamboat in motion, whence it has been termed the "Steamboat Spring." Inexhaustible coal fields skirt the Rocky Mountains through 12 degrees of latitude, chiefly in British territory. The route of the Canadian Pacific Railway is through this coal district, and crosses the Rocky Mountains by the Kicking Horse Pass.

ST. BONIFACE,

The Town of St Boniface, opposite the city of Winnipeg, is remarkable for its religious, educational and charitable institutions. It is but natural that it should be so, as St Boniface has seen the first church, the first school and the first hospital in the country. There is an iron traffic and passenger bridge between St Boniface and Winnipeg, making St Boniface virtually a suburb of Winnipeg. Population 2,000. Mail daily.

SASKATCHEWAN,
A river of the North West Territories, takes its rise in the Rocky Mountains, in a small lake near Mount Forbes, in about lat. 51 deg. 50 m. N. Winding amongst
The mountain spurs near its source it follows a N.E. direction to Peace River Pass, thence it runs N.N.E., to the foot of Big Horn Hill, whence, having preserved the streamlet of that name, it marches eastward to Mountain House. From this point to Fort Edmonton its general direction is N.E.; it continues in the same direction until it crosses the 56th parallel of latitude, along which it runs and then turns southward towards Fort Pitt, and thus, between the latter and Fort Edmonton, describes a large and almost regular curve. From Fort Pitt the river continues its S.E. course to the Eskimo, whence it turns suddenly towards the N.E., first reaching Carleton House and thence Cumberland House. From the latter point its general course is S.E., although its great winding sometimes carries it towards the N.W., and sometimes towards the S. This great river divides into many branches that flow capriciously through the vast plains which they cut in various, and frequently quite opposite, directions. Clearwater River joins it near Mountain House, and 75 miles farther down it receives Brazeau River, called also North Branch. From its source to Mountain House, a distance of about 150 miles, the Saskatchewan is not navigable. From Mountain House to Edmonton, about 150 miles, it is navigable with barges, and from Edmonton to Carleton House, about 500 miles, with steamers during a couple of months, some years for a longer period. Between Carleton and Lake Winnipeg the river is very well fitted for navigation, except for 20 miles between Cedar Rapids and Lake Winnipeg, and along the same distance in Coal Rapids near the junction of the southern branch, about 50 miles below Carleton. Total length of the Saskatchewan about 1,200 miles. The northern branch of the Saskatchewan has three main sources, all flowing from the Rocky Mountains, viz.: Gros Ventres, Bow and Red Deer Rivers. From the south bank of this great river N.W. to Peace River the climate is adapted to the growth of wheat. Coal, salt, iron, gold and bitumen are among the products to be found. For hundreds of miles wild cattle can be seen grazing in countless herds. The valley of the Saskatchewan is fitted to sustain as dense an agricultural population as any area of equal extent on the face of the globe. This valley is supposed to be peopled by 17,000 Indians. Saskatchewan is an abbreviation of the Cree word "Kisiskatenewan" (rapid stream).

SELKIRK,

An incorporated town in the county of Laskar, on the west bank of the Red River 22 miles north of Winnipeg. It is the county town. The County Court and Registry office are located here. The terminus of the Selkirk branch of the C.P.R., Selkirk is the head of deep water navigation. The Winnipeg and Western Navigation Co.'s boats run between here and Grand Rapids. There is a saw-mill, several general stores and hotels, telegraph and express offices. Mail from Winnipeg on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays; return Monday, Wednesday and Friday. There are Episcopal, Methodist, Presbyterian and Roman Catholic churches and public school. Population 300. Stages leave Selkirk for Winnipeg and Pepin, Tuesday and Saturday, 2 p.m.; leaves Pepin, Monday and Wednesday, 6 a.m.

WHITEMOUTH,
A town on the main line of the C.P.R., at the crossing of the Whitemouth River, 61 miles east of Winnipeg. Has large first class railway station; has also post office, telegraph and express offices. Mail daily. Has a Methodist church and mission service by Episcopal, Presbyterian and Roman Catholic clergy. A public school with a daily average of 60. It has 3 hotels, 2 general stores and saw mills. It has good water privileges on Whitemouth River. The surrounding lands are timbered. The soil is of excellent quality for agricultural purposes. W. J. Corregan, Esq., J.P., cultivates some 300 acres in the vicinity of the town. Quite a number of settlers have recently commenced operations in the adjoining country. The Dominion Government it is understood purpose opening up all lands on the Whitemouth River for settlement. A large trade is done here in railway ties, lumber, timber and cord wood. Population 400.

WINNIPEGOSIS,

WINNIPEG RIVER,
A large and beautiful river of Manitoba, rises at the heights separating Ontario from the North West Territories, and flows N.W. into Lake Winnipeg. One of the sources of this river is at Saguenay Portage, afterwards expanding into Lac des Milles Lacs and flowing on as River la Sene. The whole up to Little Falls, about 65 miles, is navigable by steamers; then to River Lake 67 miles, it can only be navigated by canoes. From the beginning of River Lake to the end of Lake of the Woods, including Rainy River, which connects these two beautiful sheets of water, about 208 miles, it is navigable for steamers except at the Great Falls of St Francis. At East Portage, where it receives the waters of Lake of the Woods, it assumes its own name, and flows thence into Lake Winnipeg at Fort Alexander. This portion of the stream, for a distance of about 160 miles, has so many rapids, falls and cascades that it is only navigable for canoes and small boats. At one place the Winnipeg loses the name of White River, because the water is everywhere forming from the rapid, being very continuous. The most remarkable falls of Winnipeg River are, on the N., inside English River, which empties into Seal, and is the canoe route, via Albany River, to the port of that name on Hudson's Bay, and on the S., the chain of lakes which was formerly the canoe route via Grand Portage and Pigeon River. Vermillion Lake also drains into Winnipeg River.

City of Winnipeg:

Capital of the Province of Manitoba, situated at the junction of the Assiniboine and Red Rivers, 16 miles S. of Lake Winnipeg, 65 from St. Vincent, 900 miles from Montreal via Canada Pacific Railway, or 9000 miles via Chicago and St. Paul. Prior to 1870 Winnipeg was nothing more than a chief trading-post of the Hudson Bay Company, whose headquarters were at Fort Garry. At that date the population was estimated at 300 souls. The growth of the city since has been marvelous, and a source of astonishment to citizens as well as strangers. In the interim, Manitoba was constituted a Province of the Dominion confederation, with Winnipeg as the Provincial capital. This gave a metropolitan character to the place, and brought the elements of political autonomy in its train, making it the headquarters of the Provincial Government, where the residence of the Lieutenant-Governor and all the public departments of the Province are located, as well as the superior courts and court house and jail. The Provincial Government too have made the city the head-quarters for locally transacting business in Manitoba and the Northwest. The city was incorporated in November, 1873, when its population numbered only some 2,000. The assessment of real estate which at that time was but a little over $2,000,000, has in 1884—less than 11 years—increased to nearly $10,000,000. The territorial extent of the city is about 4,000 acres. The revenue for 1884 was about $900,000, of which $90,000 was taxes and the balance licences, etc. Bonds have been issued three by the corporation—in 1875 to the amount of $250,000 for general improvements; and in 1880 to the amount of $200,000 for the building of the Red River bridge, and in 1883 for sewage and street improvements. The mercantile and commercial interests of Winnipeg are as yet but in their infancy, but giant strides are being made in this direction. There are seven banks in the city, besides a number of business houses, the city has a handsome solid brick and stone City Hall costing over $100,000, and a police station costing $30,000. There are the solid brick Fire stations, with a paid Fire Department, 3 steam fire engines, 3 chemical engines, hook and ladder trucks, etc., with telegraph signal boxes in all parts of the city. The city is well lighted by the electric light, its sidewalks are broad and in good condition, second to none in the Dominion; the principal streets, Main street, is 132 feet wide and is paved with block pavement; several of the principal side streets are planked with 3 inch oak plank. $250,000 has been expended on a permanent sewage system. The city owns three bridges, one a railroad and traffic, and the other two private ones, all of which are free to the public. The wholesale mercantile trade is fast rising into importance, and an enormous business has recently been developed in the North-West.

The Winnipeg and Western Transportation Company have a mercantile fleet, which ply on Lake Winnipeg and the Saskatchewan river, carrying regular trips between Winnipeg and Edmonton at the base of the Rocky Mountains. There are 7 lines of rails entering Winnipeg, the main line of the C. P. R. west, the main line east, the Selkirk, Stonewall, Emerson, Gretna, and the Man. South Western Railway making it the great railroad centre of the West.

Winnipeg, besides being the political and judicial metropolis of the Northwest, has also become the educational centre. The provincial Board of Education holds its sittings here, and the city is also the seat of the University of Manitoba, to which is affiliated St. John's College, one of the oldest here; St. Boniface College, which has recently erected a magnificent building valued at $30,000, and Manitoba College, a younger but also a flourishing institution. These are supplemented by two very fine ladies' colleges, one St. John's Ladies' School being valued at $12,000, and St. Mary's Academy, a new and handsome structure just approaching completion on Notre Dame street, valued at $15,000. In addition to these higher seats of learning there are the public and separate schools, which are well attended. The growth of church congregations has also been very rapid; it is but a very few years ago that church accommodation was very limited, and the number of worshippers also was very small. To-day there are several stately church edifices and others projected. The Presbyterians have Knox Church, a very fine building costing $80,000, and the Roman Catholics have St. Mary's church, valued at $30,000, besides the Cathedral in St. Boniface. The Methodist Church of Canada have two churches, Grace and Zion—the former being a handsome edifice. The Episcopalians have also two churches in the city—Holy Trinity and Christ's Church—besides St. John Cathedral in northern suburbs and the Baptists in a comfortable frame church on Rupert street.

The industries of the city are yet in their infancy, but when the drawback occasioned by the scarcity of fuel is taken into consideration, it will be admitted that the trend in this direction is a creditable one. Within the last year or two there has been material progress made in both the character and design of many of the public and private buildings, in fact some have gone up during the past 2 years that will compare favorably with those of any other city. A good class of artisans have arrived in the city, and in the general growth of the city their handiwork has been one of the principal elements in the success that has been attained. There are two grist mills, one foundry and machine shop, six steam saw mills and lumber establishments, two breweries, two malt houses, three cigar manufacturers, two biscuit factories, and also a number of carriage and blacksmithing establishments. In this connection it may be mentioned that five or six of the leading agricultural implement manufacturers have handsome warehouses doing a thriving trade; in fact it may be stated, without fear of contradiction, that no other place of the Dominion is doing so large a trade done in farming implements as in Winnipeg. There are 75 hotels in the city, some of which are very commodious houses, and a great improvement on what existed even five years ago. There are three daily newspapers, also job printing establishments and book binderies. There is a manufactory in which stone of a very good quality is made. There are, in addition to the above, a number of minor industries. Pop. 30,000.

YORK FACTORY,
A fort of the North West Territories, on the W. coast of Hudson's Bay, at the mouth of Nelson River, lat. 57 deg. N., lon. 92 deg. 25 min. W., in times past it, as Fort Bourbon, gave fierce battle to the "Governor and Company of Adventurers of England trading into Hudson's Bay," and incensed those Arctic waters in a strife the was brought to a close only by the Treaty of Utrecht in 1713, under which the French ceded the whole country and Hudson's Bay to the English. York Factory is one of the principal trading posts of the Hudson's Bay Company. It is proposed to build a railroad from here to Prince Albert, on the Saskatchewan to connect with the Canadian Pacific, a distance of 400 miles. This would bring the Saskatchewan Valley as near to tide-water as Ontario is to tide-water at Quebec. York Factory is nearer Liverpool than New York, the distances being as follows:—York Factory to Liverpool via Hudson's Straits and Cape Farewell, the southern point of Greenland, 2,066 miles; New York to Liverpool via Cape Race and Tory Island, 2,987 miles; via Cape Race and Cape Clear, 3,029 miles.

For 200 years Hudson's Bay Company's sailing ships have traded between York Factory and Scotland. The Straits and Bay are clear of ice early in July, closing again at the end of September. Lignite coal is found in abundance at Davis Straits, and a coaling station for the projected steamship line could be established there. York Factory is the seat of the see of the Lord Bishop of Moose Cree (Church of England.)

YORK FARMERS' COUNTY,
Located on Tps. 23, 24, and 25, Rg. 2, and Tps. 24, 25, and 26, Rg. 3, and Tps. 26, Rg. 4 and 5, West of the 2nd Meridian of the Territory of Assiniboia. Nearest railway station and telegraph office, Whitewood, distant 10 miles. Pop. about 100. Mails weekly. The colony has saw and flour mills and manufacturing a good quantity of lumber. There are Methodist, Presbyterian and Episcopal churches. There are 3 post offices in the colony, Armstrong's Lake, Wallace and Yorkton.
